BALTIMORE, MD., NOVEMBER 1, 1921
"THE GREENHORN NUMBER" .
The News-Letter wishes to congratulate the Blue Jay staff on
the October and initial number of their publication. "The Greenhorn
Number," as it is called, shows marked improvement over other
issues. The majority of the copy is excellent, the drawings are fair,
and the composition and printing is decidedly better than last year.
It is to be regretted that the general tone of the magazine, however, should be lowered by a few articles which can not be defended
on the grounds of originality, humor- or style. These articles are to
be found in the main body of the publication, while more original
and far better copy is to be seen among the advertisements. It is
perfectly natural that a few "chestnuts" slip by the most vigilant
staff, but what excuse can be offered for the poem on page eight,
"Advances the Freshman"?
The only really unfavorable comment, however, seems to have
been raised by the editorials, which are certainly incongruous in a
magazine such as the Blue Jay. The first two editorials would be
good in the proper place, but that place is indisputably and distinctly
not in the columns of a humorous magazine. The humor of the last
editorial might be considered a trifle forced and banal. The students
after all are interested primarily in the humorous part of the magazine and would prefer the Editor to confine his effort to a single
page and expand his surplus energy on a closer perusal of the copy.
In spite of being open to the above criticism which we hope will
have constructive results, this issue of the Blue Jay is a credit to the
University. It is the best advertisement which we possess in the
publication field and as such deserves the support of every student.

BIDS FOR DORMS FOUND HIGHER
THAN EXPECTED

THE NEWS LETTER'S
MAILBAG

Work on the proposed dormitory for J. H. U. may not be_undertaken this year, according to a
report issued October 19. Estimates for the construction are said
to be higher than the trustees expected.
The lowest bid was $366,897
made by Franie Bros. & Haigley.
The architect, Edward L. Palmer,
Jr., is figuring on the bids to ascertain whether after specifications
of materials to be used and other
details are considered the firm will
remain the lowest bidder.
Estimates are merely for the
cost of construction and do not include heating, plumbing and other
interior work, which may run the
cost of the building above $400,000.
The Alumni Association has
$225,000, it is said, which would
necessitate raising about $175,000
more if the work were begun now.

A Column in Which the Correspondents
Are Allowed Latitude, But Shoulder the Responsibility.
All letters intended for publication
must be concise, written DI ink on
regular letter size paper, on one side
only.
No attention will be paid to anonymous letters, but names signed as an
evidence of good faith will not be
printed if request is made that they be
omitted.
The publication of a letter is not to
be taken as an indorsement of its views
by "The News-Letter, which invites the
freest discussion of matters of general
interest.

Editor of the NEWS-LETTER,
Johns Hopkins University.
DEAR SIR: After every set of
examinations the blacklist takes its
toll of athletes amid a storm of unavailing protests from the student
body. There is no doubt that a
great many of the men who find
themselves ineligible could prevent
by making half the effort before
the examinations that they make
afterwards trying to have their
marks raised. Why does not the
0. D. K. appoint a committee to
watch the student standing of the
men playing on teams, and to encourage them before it is too late?
This could most certainly be done.
A number of the students who do
not compete in athletics would be
only too glad to show their college
spirit by helping those men on the
football squad who find it utterly
impossible to do as much work as
they should at night. It might be
argued that this would lead on to
some of the men slackening their
own efforts in the hope that their
work would be taken care of for
them by others. The majority,
however, would feel that the student body appreciated the efforts
hey were making and would work
the harder.
DAVIDGE H. ROWLAND.

Goodnow And others who have returned recently from Europe report
that the conditions of student life
are so wretched that we Americans
cannot conceive how bad they are.
In Vienna students are huddled together like so many cattle in the
upper floors of barns, and are living
on the scarcest amount of food for
lack of sufficient funds to provide
better quarters and decent food.
Let us, the students of Johns
Hopkins University, show that our
hearts are in the right place and
contribute a handsome sum to the
Student Friendship Fund. One
dollar in America is worth many
times its value to the European students. Remember that in forwarding such a cause as this you are
making the future leaders of Europe better men and, consequently,
better neighbors. Our fellow students from across the sea are calling for help. Come on, FIopkins
men, let's reach across the sea and
give them our support.
FRIEND OF STUDENTS.

COTILLON BOARD MAKES ANNOUNCEMENTS REGARDING
COMING DANCES

The Cotillon Board has selected Wednesday, December 21, as
the date for its first big dance ana
plans for the affair are rapidly
taking shape. The price of the
tickets has not yet been decided
upon, but will be announced in
the near future.
In the meantime informal
dances will be held in the Civil
Engineering Building after the
football games. The first of these
will take place after the Haverford game on November 5, the
other two following the contests
with St. John's and Washington
and Lee. 1 hose wishing tickets
for the dances must make their
reservations in advance, as due to
the small floor space in the C .E.
Hall, only 100 tickets will be on
sale for each dance. The price of
the tickets will be 50 cents. The
music will be furnished by the
Student Orchestra and punch
will be served.
ACTIVITIES BUTTONS ARE
DISTRIBUTED

During every lunch hour last
week the Student Council was besieged by scores of freshmen seeking the magic button that would
provide immunity from sopho more's paddles; buttons that show
that the frosh had complied with
the Freshman Regulation that
"every freshman must be actively
participating in some recognized
student activity.
The buttons were given to all
freshmen who applied and the
name of the actiyity in which they
professed to be engaged was carefully recorded. These will be
checked up with official lists. Due
action will be taken with the unfortunate ones who procured buttons under false pretenses or
failed to obtain them at all.

The Black and Blue Jay made its has been started and is moving

first appearance on Friday. A rather novel cover design rivaled the
contents for excellence. From all
appearances this year will be a banner one for the Jay.
The next issue is scheduled to be
ready by the latter part of November. It is to be called the "Changing Time" issue; all the contents,
both literary and pictorial, are to
carry out the idea. All articles and
drawings must be in by the tenth
of November. The staff requests
all students to collaborate in making this issue a big success by gathering material, writing it up in a
Presentable form and sending it in.
All students are requested to send
the Jay to their girls. Just hand
in her name and address with your
name and the $1.25, by January,

BALTIMORE, MD., NOVEMBER 1, 1921
"THE GREENHORN NUMBER" .
The News-Letter wishes to congratulate the Blue Jay staff on
the October and initial number of their publication. "The Greenhorn
Number," as it is called, shows marked improvement over other
issues. The majority of the copy is excellent, the drawings are fair,
and the composition and printing is decidedly better than last year.
It is to be regretted that the general tone of the magazine, however, should be lowered by a few articles which can not be defended
on the grounds of originality, humor- or style. These articles are to
be found in the main body of the publication, while more original
and far better copy is to be seen among the advertisements. It is
perfectly natural that a few "chestnuts" slip by the most vigilant
staff, but what excuse can be offered for the poem on page eight,
"Advances the Freshman"?
The only really unfavorable comment, however, seems to have
been raised by the editorials, which are certainly incongruous in a
magazine such as the Blue Jay. The first two editorials would be
good in the proper place, but that place is indisputably and distinctly
not in the columns of a humorous magazine. The humor of the last
editorial might be considered a trifle forced and banal. The students
after all are interested primarily in the humorous part of the magazine and would prefer the Editor to confine his effort to a single
page and expand his surplus energy on a closer perusal of the copy.
In spite of being open to the above criticism which we hope will
have constructive results, this issue of the Blue Jay is a credit to the
University. It is the best advertisement which we possess in the
publication field and as such deserves the support of every student.

BIDS FOR DORMS FOUND HIGHER
THAN EXPECTED

THE NEWS LETTER'S
MAILBAG

Work on the proposed dormitory for J. H. U. may not be_undertaken this year, according to a
report issued October 19. Estimates for the construction are said
to be higher than the trustees expected.
The lowest bid was $366,897
made by Franie Bros. & Haigley.
The architect, Edward L. Palmer,
Jr., is figuring on the bids to ascertain whether after specifications
of materials to be used and other
details are considered the firm will
remain the lowest bidder.
Estimates are merely for the
cost of construction and do not include heating, plumbing and other
interior work, which may run the
cost of the building above $400,000.
The Alumni Association has
$225,000, it is said, which would
necessitate raising about $175,000
more if the work were begun now.

must be concise, written DI ink on

omitted.
The publication of a letter is not to
be taken as an indorsement of its views
by "The News-Letter, which invites the
freest discussion of matters of general
interest.

Editor of the NEWS-LETTER,
Johns Hopkins University.
DEAR SIR: After every set of
examinations the blacklist takes its
toll of athletes amid a storm of unavailing protests from the student
body. There is no doubt that a
great many of the men who find
themselves ineligible could prevent
by making half the effort before
the examinations that they make
afterwards trying to have their
marks raised. Why does not the
0. D. K. appoint a committee to
watch the student standing of the
men playing on teams, and to encourage them before it is too late?
This could most certainly be done.
A number of the students who do
not compete in athletics would be
only too glad to show their college
spirit by helping those men on the
football squad who find it utterly
impossible to do as much work as
they should at night. It might be
argued that this would lead on to
some of the men slackening their
own efforts in the hope that their
work would be taken care of for
them by others. The majority,
however, would feel that the student body appreciated the efforts
hey were making and would work
the harder.
DAVIDGE H. ROWLAND.

Goodnow And others who have returned recently from Europe report
that the conditions of student life
are so wretched that we Americans
cannot conceive how bad they are.
In Vienna students are huddled together like so many cattle in the
upper floors of barns, and are living
on the scarcest amount of food for
lack of sufficient funds to provide
better quarters and decent food.
Let us, the students of Johns
Hopkins University, show that our
hearts are in the right place and
contribute a handsome sum to the
Student Friendship Fund. One
dollar in America is worth many
times its value to the European students. Remember that in forwarding such a cause as this you are
making the future leaders of Europe better men and, consequently,
better neighbors. Our fellow students from across the sea are calling for help. Come on, FIopkins
men, let's reach across the sea and
give them our support.
FRIEND OF STUDENTS.

COTILLON BOARD MAKES ANNOUNCEMENTS REGARDING
COMING DANCES

The Cotillon Board has selected Wednesday, December 21, as
the date for its first big dance ana
plans for the affair are rapidly
taking shape. The price of the
tickets has not yet been decided
upon, but will be announced in
the near future.
In the meantime informal
dances will be held in the Civil
Engineering Building after the
football games. The first of these
will take place after the Haverford game on November 5, the
other two following the contests
with St. John's and Washington
and Lee. 1 hose wishing tickets
for the dances must make their
reservations in advance, as due to
the small floor space in the C .E.
Hall, only 100 tickets will be on
sale for each dance. The price of
the tickets will be 50 cents. The
music will be furnished by the
Student Orchestra and punch
will be served.
ACTIVITIES BUTTONS ARE
DISTRIBUTED

During every lunch hour last
week the Student Council was besieged by scores of freshmen seeking the magic button that would
provide immunity from sopho more's paddles; buttons that show
that the frosh had complied with
the Freshman Regulation that
"every freshman must be actively
participating in some recognized
student activity.
The buttons were given to all
freshmen who applied and the
name of the actiyity in which they
professed to be engaged was carefully recorded. These will be
checked up with official lists. Due
action will be taken with the unfortunate ones who procured buttons under false pretenses or
failed to obtain them at all.
